DT Article
TI ORTHOPTERA COLLECTED DURING THE EXPEDITION 'ETHIOPIA, 100 YEARS AFTER
   VITTORIO BOTTEGO' AND PRESERVED IN THE MUSEO CIVICO DI STORIA NATURALE
   'G. DORIA' OF GENOA.
AU Massa, Bruno (bruno.massa@unipa.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 111
PS 25-42
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In 1994 the Italian association "Ricerche ed Esplorazioni Geografiche"
   organized a new expedition to Ethiopia, "Ethiopia, 100 years after
   Vittorio Bottego". Ca. 1,800 insects and other invertebrates were
   collected. The scientific support and collecting tools were provided by
   Roberto Poggi, who sent recently to the author Orthoptera to be
   identified. Here the list of the species is presented. On the whole,
   specimens belong to 28 species (3 Ensifera and 25 Caelifera), generally
   widespread in tropical Africa or endemic to Ethiopia (e.g., Stenoscepa
   boranensis (Salfi, 1939)). Among them a male and a female of a new
   species was identified, Eyprepocnemis poggii n. sp. with reduced
   tegmina, and a key to the brachypterous Eyprepocnemis has been carried
   out. In addition, a male of one unidentified Brachycrotaphus from the
   Omo Valley was found, very probably belonging to a new species; this
   genus needs a revision, the description of some species is very short
   and not useful to discriminate them from the others or based on a female
   sex only, while distinctive characters are only in the males. Thus, for
   the moment it remained unidentified, but a table with the list of all
   available information on characters of till now known species known
   species is summarized.
C1 Massa, Bruno; Univ Palermo, Dipartimento Sci Agr Alimentari & Forestali,
   Viale Sci Ed 4A, Palermo, I-90128, Italy, Italy.
EM bruno.massa@unipa.it
SC Zoology; Education &Educational Research
SN 0365-4389

   and man; Education and entertainment; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Palaearctic region; Africa; Eurasia; Europe
DE Eyprepocnemis [Africa /  / Key to species]. 
   Eyprepocnemis poggii [Ethiopia /  / New species]. 
   Orthoptera [Museums collections and exhibitions / Museo Civico di Storia
   Naturale G. Doria / Ethiopian collection list] [Expeditions / Expedition
   100 years after Vittorio Bottego / Museum collection] [Ethiopia /  /
   faunal list] [Italy / Genoa / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Orthoptera (Insecta).

   subordinate taxa, P. 39]. 
   Eyprepocnemis - Fieber 1853 (Saltatoria): [Key to species, Africa, P.
   33]. 
   Eyprepocnemis poggii (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Ethiopia, P. 31].

DT Article
TI A new species of Cebrio from Peloponnese (southern Greece) (Coleoptera,
   Elateridae, Elaterinae, Cebrionini).
FT Un nuovo Cebrio del peloponneso (coleoptera, Elateridae, Elaterinae,
   cebrionini).
AU Rattu, Roberto (robertorattu@unica.it) 
   Liberto, Andrea
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 111
PS 43-55
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cebrio (Cebrio) nestor n. sp. from Peloponnese (locus typicus: Messinia,
   Petrohori) is described, illustrated and compared with the two Cebrio
   species formerly known to occur in Greece (Cebrio (Tibesia) antennatus
   Chevrolat 1874 and Cebrio (Cebrio) insularis Chevrolat 1874). The new
   species is easily recognized from C. (T.) antennatus by the whole set of
   subgeneric characters separating Cebrio s.str. from Tibesia, such as
   antennae reaching half lenght of body, clypeus not abruptly sloping on
   labium and partly concealing it when seen from above, hemispherical
   protruding eyes, outer margin of foretibiae not serrated, shape of
   aedeagus, and furthermore by its much greater size and stouter habitus.
   The new species is well distinct from Cebrio (C.) insularis as well, at
   least by its larger size, stouter habitus, better impressed elytral
   striae, labium weakly emarginate in the middle of its distal margin,
   posterior angles of pronotum without spine-like apophysis, antennae
   barely exceeding half of the body.
C1 Rattu, Roberto; Via Pozzetto 1, Cagliari, CA, I-09126, Italy, Italy.
EM robertorattu@unica.it
SC Zoology
SN 0365-4389
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Cebrio (Cebrio) nestor [Greece /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Elateroidea,
   Cebrionidae
OR Cebrio (Cebrio) nestor (Cebrionidae): [Sp nov, Greece, P. 46]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15509059643
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15509059645
DT Article
TI ON THE IDENTITY OF LIXUS ISSELII GESTRO, 1889 WITH NOTES ON THE GENUS
   MICROLARINUS HOCHHUTH, 1847.
AU Colonnelli, Enzo (ecolonnelli@yahoo.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 111
PS 73-88
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of all Microlarinus thus far described let to discover the
   following new synonymies: Microlarinus brevirostris Marshall, 1921 (= M.
   abyssinicus Hustache, 1938, n. syn.); M. lypriformis (Wollaston, 1861)
   (= Lixus isselii Gestro, 1889, n. syn.; = M. angustulus Marshal), 1921,
   n. syn.; = M. decorsei Hustache, 1923, n. syn.; = M. erythreanus
   Hustache, 1938, n. syn.); M. rhinocylloides Hochhuth, 1847 M. diecki
   Faust, 1890, n. syn.). It is pointed out once again that M. lareynii
   (Jacquelin du Val, 1853) is the same as M. rhinocylloides Hochhuth,
   1847. It was also discovered that Meotiorhynchus punjabensis
   Gandhi&Pajni, 1984 actually belongs in Microlarinus and that differs in
   nothing from M. rhinocylloides, n. comb. et n. syn. A key to species and
   a catalogue of all hitherto described Microlarinus are included, as well
   as photos of some of the types dealt with in the note.
C1 Colonnelli, Enzo; Via Giunchiglie 56, Rome, I-00175, Italy, Italy.
EM ecolonnelli@yahoo.it
SC Zoology
SN 0365-4389
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Lixus isselii - Gestro 1889 (Curculionidae): [Referred to, Microlarinus,
   p. 73]. 
   Microlarinus - Hochhuth 1847 (Curculionidae): [Key to species, P. 78]. 
   Microlarinus brevirostris - Marshall 1928 (Curculionidae): [Syn nov,
   Microlarinus abyssinicus Hustache 1938, p. 78]. 
   Microlarinus isselii - (Gestro 1889) (Curculionidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Lixus, p. 73]. 
   Microlarinus lypriformis - (Wollaston 1861) (Curculionidae): [Syn nov,
   Microlarinus angustulus Marshall 1921, p. 75; Syn nov, Microlarinus
   decorsei Hustache 1923, p. 77; Syn nov, Microlarinus erythreanus
   Hustache 1938, p. 77; Syn nov, Microlarinus isselii (Gestro 1889), p.
   77]. 
   Microlarinus rhinocylloides - Hochhuth 1847 (Curculionidae): [Syn nov,
   Meotiorhynchus punjabensis Gandhi & Pajni 1984, p. 78; Syn nov,
   Microlarinus diecki Faust 1890, p. 77].

TI Contribution to the systematic rearrangement of the West-Palaearctic
   Peritelini. XIII. Revision to the genus Pseudomeira Stierlin, 1881: the

VL 111
PS 145-221

PY 2018
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Pseudomeira necessaria (Gyllenhal, 1834) species group is revised, a
   new species is described and illustrated (Ps. rusadirensis n. sp. from
   Moroc) and a new synonymy is proposed. For each species detailed
   comparative description, synonymic, ecological, distributional notes,
   and literature records are given. Drawings of taxonomically significant
   features, distributional maps and a key to species are included.

AN ZOOR15509059648
DT Article
TI Systematic observations on Cebrio (Tibesia) strictus 'v.' doderoi Leoni,
   1906 (Coleoptera, Elateridae, Elaterinae, Cebrionini).
FT Considerazioni sistematiche su Cebrio (tibesia) strictus 'v.' doderoi
   Leoni, 1906 (coleoptera, Elateridae, Elaterinae, Cebrionini).
AU Rattu, Roberto (robertorattu@libero.it) 
   Fois, Francesco
   Cillo, Davide
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 111
PS 223-240
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present contribution, the taxonomic status of Cebrio strictus
   "v." doderoi Leoni, 1906, is revised and changed into Cebrio (Tibesia)
   doderoi stat. nov. The examination of the Holotype of Cebrio strictus
   "v." doderoi Leoni, 1906 and of additional specimens from the immediate
   surroundings of the type locality, revealed several morphological
   differences which easily separate the "variety" described by Leoni from
   C. (T.) strictus Gene, 1836. C. (T.) doderoi stat. nov. is easily
   distinguishable from C. (T.) strictus by the following morphological
   features: the strong protrusion (in comparison to the temple) of the
   eyes, which are larger and more globular than in strictus, and the
   presence of a strongly narrow subocular space; the shape of the
   pronotum, usually subrectangular in strictus and trapezoidal in doderoi;
   the colour of dorsal side, usually bicolor in strictus but with a
   uniform coloration in doderoi; the pubescence, usually recumbent or
   reclined in strictus while reclined or raised (rarely semierected) in
   doderoi; serration of the antennae which in strictus are more serrated
   between 4-10 antennomeres. C. (T.) doderoi, stat. nov. seems to be
   morphologically more similar to C. (T.) melonii Rattu, 2014 from which
   can be separated by the stouter complexion; the coloration of the dorsal
   side (usually blackish, piceous, or dark brown); the pubescence, which
   can be reclined or raised (rarely semierected); the tergite VIII which
   is shorter and larger. So far, C. (T.) doderoi is known to occur only on
   a very short coastal stretch in the extreme south-western sector of
   Sardinia, near the village of Portoscuso and in the immediate
   surroundings. The ecology of the species appears to be linked to the
   coastal and sub-coastal environments characterized by sandy soil. C.
   (T.) melonii shares the same ecological needs. Samplings conducted in
   other sandy coastal biotopes in south-west Sardinia led to the discovery
   of other populations of Cebrio which are attributable to the subgenus
   Tibesia, still under study.
C1 Rattu, Roberto; Via Pozzetto 1, Cagliari, CA, I-09126, Italy, Italy.
EM robertorattu@libero.it
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0365-4389
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status;
   General morphology; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe; Italy
DE Cebrio (Tibesia) [General morphology /  / systematics] [Ecology /  / ]
   [Sardinia /  / biology; distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Elateroidea,
   Cebrionidae
OR Cebrio (Tibesia) - Leach 1824 (Cebrionidae). 
   Cebrio (Tibesia) doderoi - Leoni 1906 (Cebrionidae): [Redescription,
   Male, p. 226; Raised from, Cebrio (Tibesia) strictus var. doderoi, p.
   224]. 
   Cebrio (Tibesia) strictus - Gene 1836 (Cebrionidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Cebrio (Tibesia) strictus var. doderoi Leoni 1906, p. 224]. 
   Cebrio (Tibesia) strictus var. doderoi - Leoni 1906 (Cebrionidae):
   [Removal from synonymy, With Cebrio (Tibesia) strictus Gene 1836, p.
   224; Raised to, Cebrio (Tibesia) doderoi, p. 224].

DT Article
TI Malthodes (Coleoptera, Cantharidae) in the collection of Agostino
   Dodero, housed at the Museo Civico di Storia Naturale 'G. Doria', Genoa.
FT I malthodes (coleoptera, Cantharidae) della collezione di Agostino
   Dodero, conservata nel Museo Civico di Storia Naturale 'g. Doria' di
   genova.
AU Liberti, Gianfranco (gianfrancoliberti@alice.it) 
   Poggi, Roberto
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 111
PS 241-303
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Subject of this paper are the nearly 2000 Malthodes, mainly from Italy,
   of the important collection assembled by Agostino Dodero, totalling
   approximately 100 species, including a few "new" ones and several
   remarkable specimens, either types or with gegraphical or historical
   interest (for example because determined by early specialists, as Baudi
   di Selve, Pic, Ganglbauer and others). The results have been split in
   three parts. The first one reports a detailed catalogue of all Malthodes
   specimens found in collection Dodero, grouped by species sets with
   morphological affinities (as proposed in LIBERTI 2016); the list
   follows, as faithfully as possible, the collection actual disposition
   and reports all the labelling details. In the second part both types and
   other relevant specimens found have been commented. Thanks to the
   retrieval of several types, the proposal of three new synonymies has
   been possible: Malthodes (Maltharcus) laciniatus subsp. agrigentinus
   Fiori, 1915 = Malthodes hastulifer Kiesenwetter, 1871, Podistrina
   doderoi Bourgeois, 1903 = Malthodes cruciatus Baudi, 1859 and
   Mesomalthodes dispar ab. nigrinus Fiori, 1905 = Malthodes dispar
   (Germar, 1824). In the third part (by GL) three new species and one new
   subspecies are described: Malthodes leptopygus n. sp. from Sardinia,
   Malthodes dyacanthus n. sp. from Sardinia, Malthodes fantii n. sp. from
   the Argentario Mount (Grosseto province) and Malthodes debilis n. ssp.
   pedemontanus from southern Piedmont and the Apennines mountain range.
   The neotype of Malthodes debilis ssp. debilis has been also defined.

   Italy.

DT Article
TI Anopolenus henrici Salter, a middle Cambrian Drumian centropleurid
   trilobite from the Alum Shale Formation of Scandinavia.
AU Weidner, Thomas
   Ebbestad, Jan Ove R. (to.we@paradis.dk) 
SO Bulletin of the Geological Society of Denmark
VL 66
PS 223-228
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Centropleurid trilobites include five genera of which Centropleura
   Angelin, Anopolenus Salter, Clarella Howell and Luhops Snajdr are known
   from eight species in the traditional middle Cambrian (Miaolingian
   Series, Drumian Stage) of Sweden and Denmark (Bornholm). Beishanella
   Xiang&Zhang has not been recorded in Scandinavia so far, and no
   centropleurids have been reported from Norway. Of these taxa, only
   Centropleura is common in Scandinavia. Two pygidia previously identified
   as Centropleura sp. and Anopolenus sp. from erratics in Germany and
   Bornholm, respectively, as well as a new pygidum from Scania in Sweden
   are here identified as Anopolenus henrici Salter. Elsewhere, the species
   is known from Wales, Avalonian Canada, Siberia, Alaska, and Sardinia,
   occurring in the A. atavus and P. punctuosus zones (the former in
   Siberia only). The presence of this species increases the known
   diversity of Centropleuridae in Scandinavia and is important for
   correlation between Baltica and Avalonia.
C1 Ebbestad, Jan Ove R.; Uppsala Univ, Museum Evolut, Norbyvagen 22,
   Uppsala, SE-75236, Sweden, Sweden.
EM to.we@paradis.dk
SC Zoology
SN 0011-6297

   Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Anopolenus henrici [Zoogeography / Palaeobiogeography / New record;
   systematics] [Denmark /  / ] [Germany /  / ] [Sweden /  / ] [Cambrian /
   Drumian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Trilobites
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Trilobitomorpha, Trilobita
OR Anopolenus henrici - Salter 1864 (Trilobita): [Fossil; New record].

TI A new small chiton (Mollusca: Polyplacophora) from Guadelupe.
AU Sirenko, Boris I. (marine@zin.ru) 
SO Byulleten' Dal'nevostochnogo Malakologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 22
IS 1-2
PS 55-62
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Leptochiton guadelupei sp. nov. from near Guadelupe in western Atlantic
   is described. The new species differs from other western Atlantic
   species of the genus Leptochiton by having a unique sculpture of
   tegmentum in the form of concentric rows of granules and the unidentate
   cusp of the major lateral tooth of radula, which has a deep longitudinal
   groove on each side.

DT Article
TI A new bat record for the late Pleistocene of Jamaica: Pteronotus
   trevorjacksoni from the Red Hills Road Cave.
AU Ostende, Lars W. Van den Hoek (Lars.vandenHoekOstende@naturalis.nl) 
   Van Oijen, Delia
   Donovan, Stephen K.
SO Caribbean Journal of Earth Science
VL 50
PS 31-35
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Jamaican Red Hills Road Cave is known for its late Pleistocene bat
   fauna. Continued screening of the material has yielded fossil material
   of a species Pteronotus of similar size to P. parnellii, which currently
   inhabits the island. However, the dentition of the new finds is
   characterized by plump molars, quite unlike that of the recent
   representatives. Therefore, the Red Hills Road Cave material is
   considered to belong to a new species, Pteronotus trevorjacksoni sp.
   nov. The find of a fully unworn P4 suggests that P. trevorjacksoni may
   have roosted in the cave; Pteronotus species are still cave dwellers.
C1 Ostende, Lars W. Van den Hoek; Naturalis Biodivers Ctr, Next Generat
   Biodivers Discovery, Postbus 9517, Leiden, NL-2300 RA, Netherlands,
   Netherlands.
EM Lars.vandenHoekOstende@naturalis.nl

SN 0799-0901

   zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary

AN ZOOR15509056840
DT Article
TI Invasive Rats (Rattus sp.), but not always Mice (Mus musculus), are
   Ubiquitous at All Elevations and Habitats within the Caribbean National
   Forest, Puerto Rico.
AU Shiels, Aaron B. (aaron.b.shiels@aphis.usda.gov) 
   de Arellano, Gabriela E. Ramirez
SO Caribbean Naturalist
VL 48
PS 1-14
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Invasive rodents, particularly rats (Rattus spp.), occupy >80% of the
   world's islands and are among the greatest threats to native
   biodiversity and agriculture on islands. At the time of their
   introduction in the 1500s, there was at least 1 native rat species in
   Puerto Rico. Today there are no native rodents remaining in Puerto Rico,
   but R. norvegicus (Norway Rat) may be found in urban settings, and R.
   rattus (Black Rat) are the most common rat across the island including
   within natural areas, and invasive Mus musculus (House Mouse) may also
   be found in urban and non-urban habitats. The Caribbean National Forest
   (CNF; locally El Yunque) in northeastern Puerto Rico has some native and
   endangered species vulnerable to rat predation. The objective of our
   study was to determine the presence and distribution of invasive rodents
   (rats and mice) across elevations and habitats within the CNF. We used
   104 tracking tunnels, which are baited ink cards placed in tunnels so
   that foot prints of animal visitors could be identified, to determine
   presence of invasive rodent species. We placed 3 tracking tunnels at
   each 50-m elevation-gain (n = 66 total tunnels), on the edge of forest
   habitat from sea level to 1070 m at El Yunque peak along the main road
   (Highway 191) through the CNF. We established additional tracking
   tunnels (n = 38) in the major habitats in the CNF, including treefall
   and hurricane gaps, landslides, stream edges, and continuous forest.
   House Mice had not been previously reported in the CNF, and were found
   only at the forest edge along Highway 191 at elevations of 50-150 m and
   300-1070 m, whereas rats (Rattus sp.) were found at all elevations and
   in all habitat types sampled. Logistic regressions revealed that mice
   and rat presence each increases with elevation (mice: P = 0.0352, rat: P
   = 0.0019), though total rodent presence did not. Knowledge of the
   habitat types and elevations that these invasive rodents occupy can
   inform management strategies for rodent control and native species
   protection.
C1 Shiels, Aaron B.; USDA, Natl Wildlife Res Ctr, 4101 LaPorte Ave, Ft
   Collins, CO, 80521, USA, USA.
EM aaron.b.shiels@aphis.usda.gov
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 2326-7119
BD Ecology; Abiotic factors; Physical factors; Zoogeography; Dispersal;
   Means of dispersal; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America;
   West Indies
DE Mus musculus; Rattus [Habitat utilization / Habitat associations /
   presence & distribution] [Altitude / Elevation / ] [Introduction /
   Invasive species / ] [Puerto Rico / Caribbean National Forest / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae
OR Mus musculus (Muridae). 
   Rattus (Muridae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15509056840
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15509055970

TI A new species of the genus Carpophilus (Coleoptera: Nitidulidae:
   Carpophilinae) from Algeria, and taxonomic notes.
AU Kirejtshuk, A.G. (agk@zin.ru) 
   Kovalev, A., V
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 14
SU S
PS 3-8
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Carpophilus (Carpophilus) saharaensis sp. n. belonging to the
   bifenestratus-group, which is distributed mostly in the Afro-Malagasy
   (Afrotropical, Capean and Malagasy) Regions, is described from Algeria
   (Theniet el Had). This group is first proposed. Its diagnosis,
   composition, variability and distribution are discussed. The lectotypes
   of Carpophilus (Carpophilus) bifenestratus Murray, 1864, C. (C.)
   biguttatus Klug, 1862 and C. (C.) binotatus Murray, 1864 are designated.
   The renewed synonymy for the species name C. (C.) bifenestratus and also
   the information on variability of this species and probable synonymy
   with Carpophilus (Carpophilus) bipustulatus (Heer, 1841) (Ips) are
   given. 'The latter name needs a re-examination of the type series used
   for its proposal.

TI Taxonomical changes, comments and new country records of West
   Palaearctic Chrysomelidae (Coleoptera ) with special regards to
   Mediterranean species.
AU Bezdek, J. (bezdek@mendelu.cz) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 14
SU S
PS 17-27
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Based on the study of primary type material, the following taxonomic
   changes in West Palaearctic Chrysomelidae are proposed: Chilotomina
   moroderi moroderi (Escalera, 1928) = Gynandrophthalma moroderi Cobos,
   1969, syn. n.; Cryptocephalus (Burlinius) macellus Suffrian, 1860 = C.
   zantensis Pic, 1953, syn. n.; Chrysolina (Bittotaenia) salviae
   (Sahlberg, 1823) = Chrysomela salviae Germar, 1823, syn. n.; Timarcha
   geniculata (Sahlberg, 1823) = Chrysomela geniculata Germar, 1823, syn.
   n.; Calomicrus lividus (Joannis, 1865) = Calomicrus trabzonus Lopatin et
   Nesterova, 2013, syn. n.; Euluperus azureus (Fairmaire, 1884), comb. n.
   (from Calomicrus) = Euluperus hermonensis Lopatin, 1997, syn. n.;
   Euluperus nairicus (Lopatin, 1990), comb. n. (from Calomicrus); Exosoma
   gaudionis (Reiche, 1862) = Exosoma Thoracica var. grossepunctata Roubal,
   1931, syn. n.; Exosoma lusitanicum (Linnaeus, 1767) = Malacosoma theryi
   Guillebeau, 1897, syn. n.; Monolepta syriaca (Weise, 1924), comb. n.
   (from Calomicrus) = Calomicrus volkovitshi Lopatin et Nesterova, 2013,
   syn. n.; Theone silphoides silphoides (Sahlberg, 1823) = Galleruca
   silphoides Dalman, 1823, syn. n.; Derocrepis rufipes (Linnaeus, 1758) =
   Chrysomela caeruleostriata DeGeer, 1775, syn. n. Moreover,
   Gynandrophthalma transsylvanica Frivaldszky, 1883 is confirmed as
   synonym of Smaragdina salicina (Scopoli, 1763) and Chrysomela
   plantaginis DeGeer, 1775 is confirmed as synonym of Phaedon armoraciae
   (Linnaeus, 1758). It is shown that Carolus Reginald Sahlberg published
   the oldest descriptions of Chrysolina salviae (Germar, 1823), Timarcha
   geniculata (Germar, 1823) and Theone silphoides silphoides (Dalman,
   1823) and the authorship of these species is changed. Lectotypes are
   designated for Luperus azureus Fairmaire, 1884 and Luperus brevicollis
   Weise, 1898. New country records for West Palaearctic Chrysomelidae
   (with special regards to Mediterranean fauna) are presented.

DT Article
TI A new species of Empis Linnaeus, 1758 (Diptera: Empididae) from Morocco,
   with a key to Coptophlebia-like species of the Mediterranean basin.
AU Shamshev, I., V (shamshev@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 14
SU S
PS 35-39
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Empis (Empis) nikita sp. n. is described from Morocco. The new species
   belongs to a group of species with incomplete vein M1 that was placed
   earlier to the subgenus Coptophlebia Bezzi, 1909. The new species
   differs from all species of Empis s. str. by the structure of abdominal
   sternite 7 of the male which has long, hornlike projection curved
   anteriorly. A key to species of Empis s. str. with incomplete vein M1
   known from the Mediterranean basin is compiled for the first time.
C1 Shamshev, I., V; Russian Acad Sci, Zool Inst, Univ Skaya Emb 1, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM shamshev@mail.ru
SC Zoology

   Palaearctic region; Africa

   species].

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Orthorrhapha,
   Empididae
OR Empis (Empis) - Linnaeus 1758 (Empididae): [Key to species, Palaearctic
   region, Mediterranean basin, Species with with incomplete vein M1, p.
   38].

PT J
AN ZOOR15509055976
DT Article
TI Owlflies (Neuroptera: Ascalaphidae) of Crimea and alied taxa from the
   West Palaearctic.
AU Krivokhatsky, V.A. (krivokhatsky@yandex.ru) 
   Bagaturov, M.F.
   Prokopov, G.A.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 14
SU S
PS 41-74
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Since the first information at the end of the 19th Century and up to the
   present time, the only species of the family Ascalaphidae has been
   registered in Crimea: Libelloides macaronius (Scopoli, 1763) with two
   subspecies, L. macaronius kolyvanensis (Laxmann, 1770) (= Ascalaphus
   longicornis dubius Eversmann, 1850, syn. n.) and L macaronius pupillatus
   (Rambur, 1842). Each listed subspecies has two colour morphs. Yellow
   (morpha typica) and white (morpha alba n.) morphs of the subspecies L.
   macaronius kolyvanensis (Laxmann, 1770) can be found together in
   south-east part of Crimea. The second subspecies with two colour morphs,
   L. macaronius pupillatus (Rambur, 1842) morpha typica and morpha
   intermedia (Menetries, 1849), is definitely extinct in Crimea and occurs
   now in the Kuban and the Volga regions. Subspecific and infrasubspecific
   structure of Libelloides macaronius is discussed. The key to all
   subspecies from the Ancient Mediterranean zoogeographical region is
   given. Information about their bionomics, distribution and occurrence in
   Crimea over the past 100 years are added. Brief diagnoses of taxa and
   descriptions of L. macaronius kolyvanensis alba, morpha n. is given. The
   rank of two species is changed: Libelloides macaronius tajikus Luppova,
   1973, stat. n. and L. macaronius oculatus (Brae, 1832), stat. n. =
   Ascalaphus kolyvanensis var. ponticus McLachlan, 1876, syn. n. Two
   subspecies are reduced to morphs: Libelloides longicornis (Linnaeus,
   1764), morpha leucocelia Costa, 1855; Libelloides macaronius pupillatus
   (Rambur, 1842) morpha intermedia Menetries, 1849. Some ascalaphid taxa
   from the Central Palaearctic are interpreted as subspecies of
   Libelloides macaronius described on the base of typical yellow morphs:
   L. macaronius turcestanicus (Weele, 1909) and L. macaronius trimaculatus
   (Weele, 1909). In addition, two white morphs, L. macaronius
   turcestanicus doboszi morpha n. and L. macaronius trimaculatus letardii
   morpha n., are described. White morpha was not found for L. macaronius
   tajikus Luppova, 1973, stat. n. Among Asian taxa, the specimen described
   by L. Navas as variation, transferred here to the rank aberration
   Libelloides macaronius kolyvanensis ab. fumata (Navas, 1929), which does
   not form the biological taxon.
C1 Krivokhatsky, V.A.; Russian Acad Sci, Zool Inst, Univ Skaya Emb 1, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM krivokhatsky@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Ascalaphidae [Ukraine / Crimea / Distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Neuroptera
OR Ascalaphidae (Neuroptera). 
   Ascalaphus oculatus - Brulle 1832 (Neuroptera): [Downgraded to,
   Libelloides macaronius oculatus, p. 60]. 
   Ascalaphus tajiku - Luppova 1973 (Neuroptera): [Downgraded to,
   Libelloides macaronius tajikus, p. 64]. 
   Libelloides macaronius (Neuroptera): [Key to subspecies, P. 65]. 
   Libelloides macaronius kolyvanensis - Laxmann 1770 (Neuroptera): [Syn
   nov, Ascalaphus longicornis dubius Eversmann 1850, p. 53]. 
   Libelloides macaronius oculatus - Brulle 1832 (Neuroptera): [Downgraded
   from, Ascalaphus oculatus, p. 60]. 
   Libelloides macaronius tajikus - Luppova 1973 (Neuroptera): [Downgraded
   from, Ascalaphus tajiku, p. 64].

PT J
AN ZOOR15509056872
PM 30271995
DT Article
TI The divergence and dispersal of early perissodactyls as evidenced by
   early Eocene equids from Asia.
AU Bai, Bin (baibin@ivpp.ac.cn) 
   Wang, Yuan-Qing
   Meng, Jin
SO Communications Biology
VL 1
PS 115
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB The earliest perissodactyls are represented by some basal equoid fossils
   from Euramerica near the Paleocene/Eocene boundary. Unequivocal early
   equoids have yet to be reported from the early Eocene of Asia, although
   other groups of early perissodactyls were indeed present in Asia. Here
   we report the earliest Eocene Asian equid, Erihippus tingae gen. et sp.
   nov., based on partial specimens initially assigned to the ceratomorph
   Orientolophus hengdongensis, from the Hengyang Basin of Hunan Province,
   China. The specimens previously assigned to 'Propachynolophus'
   hengyangensis from the same Lingcha fauna are split and now reassigned
   as an ancylopod Protomoropus? hengyangensis and a brontothere Danjiangia
   lambdodon sp. nov. The nearly simultaneous appearance of equids,
   ceratomorphs, ancylopods, and brontotheres in the Hengyang Basin
   suggests that the four main groups of perissodactyls diverged as early
   as, or no later than, the beginning of the Eocene (about 56 Ma), and
   displayed different dispersal scenarios during the early Eocene.
C1 Bai, Bin; Chinese Acad Sci, Key Lab Vertebrate Evolut & Human Origins
   Chinese, Beijing, 100044, China, China.
EM baibin@ivpp.ac.cn
RI Bai, Bin/D-6898-2013
OI Bai, Bin/0000-0003-4394-8689; Wang, Yuan-Qing/0000-0002-7467-6586
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 2399-3642; 2399-3642
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; General morphology;
   Evolution; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Danjiangia lambdodon; Erihippus tingae [Hunan /  / new species] [Eocene
   /  / ]. 
   Erihippus [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Perissodactyla [General morphology / Morphological characters /
   systematics] [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic position / ] [Fossil assemblages
   /  / ] [Zoogeography / Palaeobiogeography / ] [Hunan /  / ] [Eocene /
   Early Eocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Perissodactyla, Eomoropidae,
   Equidae, Isectolophidae
OR Perissodactyla (Mammalia): [Fossil]. 
   Danjiangia lambdodon (Eomoropidae): [Sp nov, Hunan, Eocene, P. 6;
   Fossil]. 
   Erihippus (Equidae): [Gen nov, Type species Erihippus tingae, p. 2,
   Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Erihippus tingae (Equidae): [Sp nov, Hunan, Eocene, P. 2; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A SURVEY OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND PHYLOGENETIC RELATIONSHIPS OF SPECIES
   OF THE GENUS HASLUNDICHILIS WYGODZ. (ARCHAEOGNATHA, MACHILIDAE) WITH
   DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES FROM DAGHESTAN.
AU Kaplin, V.G. (ctenolepisma@mail.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 97
IS 3
PS 452-472
PD 2018
PY 2018
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Review of the 6 species of the southern Palaearctic genus Haslundichilis
   Wygodzinsky, their phylogenetic relationships and evolutionary trends
   based on comparative analysis of the geographic distribution of the
   species and of the plesiomorphic and apomorphic states of their main
   morphological features were performed for the first time. Bristletails
   of the genus Haslundichilis are common in temperate forest and steppe
   open landscapes in the foothills and mountains of the Eastern Caucasus,
   Central Asia, Northwestern and Eastern China, and South Korea. This
   genus has arisen in the forest landscapes of Western China wherefrom its
   representatives had spread eastward up to South Korea and westward up to
   the mountains of Middle Asia and Eastern Caucasus. A new species
   Haslundichilis daghestanica sp. n. is closest to H. afghani, from which
   it differs in a larger body size, narrower eyes and more developed
   sensory fields on the fore femur of male.
C1 Kaplin, V.G.; All Russian Sci Res, Inst Plant Protect, 3 Podbelsky
   Highway, Pushkin St Petersburg, 196608, Russia, Russia.
EM ctenolepisma@mail.ru
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF THE WEEVIL GENUS MECYSMODERES SCHOENHERR, 1837
   (COLEOPTERA, CURCULIONIDAE: CEUTORHYNCHINAE) FROM VIETNAM.
AU Korotyaev, B.A. (korotyay@rambler.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 97
IS 3
PS 473-482
PD 2018
PY 2018
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the weevil genus Mecysmoderes Schoenherr, 1837 are
   described from Vietnam. Mecysmoderes (Enzoellus) vladimiri sp. n.
   differs from the type species of Enzoellus and its allies from Thailand
   and Laos in the larger size, deeper meshes on the pronotum, broader legs
   and velvety black sutural spot on the elytra. Mecysmoderes
   (Xenysmoderes) sergii sp. n. in the shape, coloration and vestiture of
   the body is similar to M. consularis Pascoe, but clearly differs in the
   larger size, strongly and unevenly convex pronotal disc, swollen in
   middle part elytra, and dark scutellar spot.
C1 Korotyaev, B.A.; Russian Acad Sci, Zool Inst, Univ Embankment 1, St
   Petersburg, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI REVIEW OF THE BRACONID WASP GENUS BATHYCENTOR SAUSSURE, 1892
   (HYMENOPTERA, BRACONIDAE: DORYCTINAE) WITH DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES
   FROM CENTRAL AFRICA.
AU Belokobylskij, S.A. (doryctes@gmail.com) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 97
IS 3
PS 504-517
PD 2018
PY 2018
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The status of the Palaeotropical genus Bathycentor Saussure, 1892 and
   its taxonomic position in the tribe Rhaconotini are discussed; the first
   full descriptions of this genus and its type species B. kraesselini
   Saussure, 1892 are provided. The new species, Bathycentor trjapitzini
   sp. n., from Republic of Congo is described. The genus names Epirhacon
   Belokobylskij, 1990, syn. n. and Sinaodoryctes Chen et Shi, 2004, syn.
   n. are synonymized with Bathycentor Saussure and new combinations,
   Bathycentor laetus (Belokobylskij, 1990), comb. n., and Bathycentor
   aurus (Chen et Shi, 2004), comb. n., are made. A key to the five known
   Bathycentor species is given.

   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE APHIDIID-WASP GENUS DYSCRITULUS HINCKS, 1943

AU Davidian, E.M. (GDavidian@yandex.ru)

AB A little known Neotropical species Schizophragma saltensis Ogloblin,
   1949 (Hymenoptera, Mymaridae) is transferred to the genus Anagrus
   Haliday, 1833 as Anagrus saltensis (Ogloblin, 1949), comb. n.
   Description of the previously unknown male of A. saltensis is given, and
   a new species related to it, Anagrus (Anagrus) vatrjapitzini sp. n., is
   described from a female collected in Argentina. Both taxa belong to the
   stethynioides species group of the nominate subgenus Anagrus to which a
   key is given.

PT J
AN ZOOR15509055897
DT Article
TI TRJAPITZION SIMUTNIK, GEN. N. (HYMENOPTERA, CHALCIDOIDEA: ENCYRTIDAE), A
   NEW GENUS OF ENCYRTID WASPS FROM THE LATE EOCENE ROVNO AMBER.
AU Simutnik, S.A. (sim@izan.kiev.ua) 
   Perkovsky, E.E.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 97
IS 3
PS 539-544
PD 2018
PY 2018
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Trjapitzion cylindrocerus Simutnik, gen. et sp. n. is described based on
   female specimen from the Late Eocene Rovno amber. Brief comparative
   morphological analysis of the new taxon is made. Similarly to all
   previously described fossil Encyrtidae of the Eocene amber fauna, the
   new genus Trjapitzion is characterized by long veins of the forewing.
   Its main features are the presence of a wide parastigma, uncus, strongly
   widened scapus, and not flattened, cylindrical flagellum. Absence of
   filum spinosum allows provisional placement of the new genus to the
   subfamily Tetracneminae. The sample with the holotype also contains the
   worker ant Lasius schiefferdeckeri Mayr and aphids Germaraphis oblonga
   Heie and G. ungulata Heie. Such syninclusions had been formed in the
   lower part of the amber tree trunk, with which the hosts of the new
   encyrtids could also have been associated.
C1 Simutnik, S.A.; Natl Acad Sci Ukraine, II Schmalhausen Inst Zool, 15
   Bogdan Khmelnitsky St, Kiev, UA-01601, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM sim@izan.kiev.ua
SC Reproductive Biology; Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Reproduction; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Trjapitzion [Egg / New genus, Eocene / ] [Eocene /  / New genus
   described from fossil egg]. 
   Trjapitzion cylindrocerus [Ukraine /  / new species; Described from
   amber] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Chalcidoidea, Encyrtidae
OR Trjapitzion - Simutnik 2018 (Encyrtidae): [Gen nov, Type species
   Trjapitzion cylindrocerus, p. 540, Eocene, Described from fossil egg;
   Fossil]. 
   Trjapitzion cylindrocerus (Encyrtidae): [Sp nov, Ukraine, Eocene, P.
   540, Described from amber; Fossil].

AB Two new species of the genus Eurytoma: Eu. vatrjapitzini Zerova et
   Klymenko, sp. n. and Eu. lirae Zerova et Klymenko, sp. n. are described.
   The first belongs to the robusta group, the second, to the compressa
   group. Eurytoma vatrjapitzini sp. n. was collected in Malaise trap in
   Israel, Eu. lirae sp. n. was reared from galls on stems of Artemisia
   campestris L. (Asteraceae) in Spain. The holotypes and all paratypes of
   the new species are preserved in the collection of the Institute of
   Zoology of the National Academy of Science of Ukraine (Kyiv).

TI Two new species in the genus Heteribalia Sakagami (Hymenoptera:
   Ibaliidae) from China.
AU Chai, Miao
   Liu, Zhiwei
   Niu, Yao
   Dong, Yingying
   Wang, Yiping (wyp@zafu.edu.cn) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 40
IS 3
PS 217-230
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Heteribalia Sakagami (1949) is a member of the small parasitic
   wasp family Ibaliidae (Hymenoptera: Cynipoidea), and all known species
   of this genus are from China and its neighbouring countries. In this
   paper, we report two new species, Heteribalia miltopronotum sp. nov. and
   Heteribalia sichuanensis sp. nov., and distribution for H. divergens Maa
   (1949). These new discoveries update the known distribution of this
   genus in China from the known east coast areas to a much more extensive
   region between the eastern coast and Sichuan Province in central China.
   A key to all known Heteribalia species is provided.
C1 Wang, Yiping; Zhejiang Agr & Forestry Univ, Coll Forestry & Biotechnol,
   Linan, Zhejiang, 311300, China, China.

DT Article
TI A new species of Charinus (Amblypygi: Charinidae) from Ghana, with notes
   on West African whip spiders.
AU Harms, Danilo (danilo.harms@uni-hamburg.de) 
SO Evolutionary Systematics
VL 2
IS 1
PS 45-53
PD 2018
PY 2018
UR https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/
AW https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/article/24505/
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The fauna of whip spiders (Amblypygi) in Western Africa is poorly known
   but probably diverse. Here, I describe the new species Charinus kakum
   sp. n. based on female morphology, and accompanied by DNA sequence data.
   The species is small and differs from other African species of Charinus
   in the low number of pseudosegments on leg IV, female genital features,
   spination patterns of the pedipalp, and small body size. It was
   collected from wet tropical rainforest in Kakum National Park, Ghana and
   is only the fourth species of Charinus to be recorded from the highly
   diverse Western African biodiversity hotspot. With a total body length
   of not even 6 mm it is also one of the smallest whip spiders in the
   world.
C1 Harms, Danilo; Univ Hamburg, Ctr Nat Hist, Martin Luther King Pl 3,
   Hamburg, D-20146, Germany, Germany.
EM danilo.harms@uni-hamburg.de
SC Zoology
SN 2535-0730; 2535-0730
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Amblypygi [Africa / West Africa / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Charinus [Africa / West Africa / Distribution; systematics] [Ghana /  /
   New record]. 
   Charinus kakum [Ghana /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Amblypygi
OR Amblypygi (Arachnida). 
   Charinus (Amblypygi): [New record]. 
   Charinus kakum (Amblypygi): [Sp nov, Ghana, P. 46].

TI Taxonomic descriptions of nine new species of the goblin spider genera
   Cavisternum, Grymeus, Ischnothyreus, Opopaea, Pelicinus and
   Silhouettella (Araneae, Oonopidae) from Sri Lanka.
AU Ranasinghe, U.G.S.L.
   Benjamin, Suresh P. (suresh.benjamin@gmail.com) 
SO Evolutionary Systematics
VL 2
IS 1
PS 65-80
PD 2018
PY 2018
UR https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/
AW https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/article/25200/
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nine new species of goblin spiders are described in six different
   genera: Cavisternum bona n. sp., Grymeus dharmapriyai n. sp.,
   Ischnothyreus chippy n. sp., Opopaea spino-siscorona n. sp., Pelicinus
   snooky n. sp., P. tumpy n. sp., Silhouettella saaristoi n. sp., S.
   snippy n. sp. and S. tiggv n. sp. Three genera arc recorded for the
   first time in Sri Lanka: Cavisternum, Grymeus and Silhouettella. The
   first two genera are reported for the first time outside of Australia.
   Sri Lankan goblin spider diversity now comprises 45 described species in
   13 different genera.

DT Article
TI New species of tube web spiders of the genus Ariadna from South
   Australia (Araneae, Segestriidae).
AU Marsh, Jessica R. (marsh_jess@hotmail.com) 
   Baehr, Barbara C.
   Glatz, Richard, V
   Framenau, Volker W.
SO Evolutionary Systematics
VL 2
IS 2
PS 137-149
PD 2018
PY 2018
UR https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/
AW https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/article/29172/
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species in the tube-web spider genus Ariadna Audouin, 1826
   (Segestriidae Simon, 1893) are described from South Australia based on
   morphological features of both males and females. Ariadna clavata sp. n.
   and Ariadna tangara sp. n. are widespread and sympatric on eastern
   Kangaroo Island, where they are found beneath bark, in borer holes in
   dead wood, and in short burrows under rocks. They have also been found
   in south-eastern mainland South Australia and bring the total number of
   described Australian Ariadna to 13 species. We showcase intraspecific
   variation in both species based on a significant number of specimens,
   including substantial size variation in females and variations in
   patterns of leg spination. For male Ariadna, we also establish the
   previously unknown functions of apophyses and spines on the metatarsi
   and tibiae on the first legs, which are used during mating to clasp the
   female.
C1 Marsh, Jessica R.; POB 787, Kingscote, SA, 5223, Australia, Australia.
EM marsh_jess@hotmail.com
OI Framenau, Volker/0000-0002-7724-3831
SC Zoology
SN 2535-0730; 2535-0730
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Ariadna [Australia /  / Distribution; new record; systematics]. 
   Ariadna clavata; Ariadna tangara [South Australia /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Ariadna (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Ariadna clavata (Araneae): [Sp nov, South Australia, P. 139]. 
   Ariadna tangara (Araneae): [Sp nov, South Australia, P. 142]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15509056805

DT Article
TI The spider genus Pterotricha Kulczynski, 1903 (Araneae, Gnaphosidae) in
   the United Arab Emirates.
AU Zamani, Alireza (zamani.alireza5@gmail.com) 
SO Evolutionary Systematics
VL 2
IS 2
PS 151-161
PD 2018
PY 2018
UR https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/
AW https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/article/29981/
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Spiders of the gnaphosid genus Pterotricha Kulczynski, 1903 occurring in
   the United Arab Emirates (UAE) are surveyed on the basis of a large
   collection deposited in the American Museum of Natural History. Within
   the examined material, six species were recognized, four of which are
   described as new to science: P. arabica sp. n. ([male][female]), P.
   esyunini sp. n. ([male]), P. nadolnyi sp. n. ([male]) and P. stevensi
   sp. n. ([male]), and two are newly recorded for the fauna of the UAE: P.
   dalmasi Fage, 1929 (hitherto known from Algeria, Egypt, Sudan, Israel,
   Jordan, Saudi Arabia, and possibly Iran) and P. kovblyuki
   Zamani&Marusik, 2018 (hitherto known only from Iran). Illustrations for
   all treated species and a map of collection localities are provided.
C1 Zamani, Alireza; Univ Tehran, Sch Biol, Tehran, Iran, Iran.
EM zamani.alireza5@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 2535-0730; 2535-0730
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Pterotricha [United Arab Emirates /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Pterotricha arabica; Pterotricha esyunini; Pterotricha nadolnyi;
   Pterotricha stevensi [United Arab Emirates /  / New species].

   New record].

DT Article
TI The wolf spider genus Artoria in New South Wales and the Australian
   Capital Territory, Australia (Araneae, Lycosidae, Artoriinae).
AU Framenau, Volker W. (volker.framenau@murdoch.edu.au) 
   Baehr, Barbara C.
SO Evolutionary Systematics
VL 2
IS 2
PS 169-241
PD 2018
PY 2018
UR https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/
AW https://evolsyst.pensoft.net/article/30778/
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB The wolf spider (Lycosidae Sundevall, 1833) genus Artoria Thorell, 1877
   is revised for New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory,
   Australia, to include 34 species, 21 of which are new to science: A.
   albopilata (Urquhart, 1893), A. alta Framenau 2004, A. beaury sp. n., A.
   barringtonensis sp. n., A. belfonlensis sp. n., A. berenice (I,. Koch,
   1877), A. bondi sp. n., A. booderee sp. n., A. comletvi sp. n., A.
   corowa sp. n., A. equipalus sp. n., A. extivoldinaria sp. n., A.
   flavimana Simon, 1909, A. gloriosa (Rainbow, 1920), A. grahammilledgei
   sp. n., A. helensmithae sp. n., A. howquaensis Framenau, 2002, A.
   kanangra sp. n., A. kerewong sp. n., A. lineata (L. Koch, 1877), A.
   mamota sp. n.,A. mckayi Framenau, 2002, A. mungo sp. n.,A. munmorah sp.
   n., A. myallensis sp. n., A. quadrata Framenau, 2002, A. slatyeri sp.
   n., A. strepera sp. n., A. taeniifera Simon, 1909, A. terania sp. n., A.
   triangularis Framenau, 2002, A. ulrichi Framenau, 2002, A. victoriensis
   Framenau, Gotch&Austin, 2006, and A. wilkiei sp. n. L ycosa pruinosa L.
   Koch, 1877, currently listed in Artoria, is considered a nomen dubium.
   Artoria are largely forest dwellers, although some species have
   preferences for more open areas such as riparian or coastal environments
   or grasslands. Consequently, the genus mainly occurs east and west along
   the Great Dividing Range, although some species can be found into the
   Riverina, Cobar Peneplain and Darling Riverine Plains IBRA regions to
   the wes

PT J
AN ZOOR15509056967
DT Article
TI A revision of Gyrocochlea-grade Charopidae from mid-eastern Queensland
   and redescription and generic reassignment of three Gyrocochlea-grade
   species (Eupulmonata: Charopidae).
AU Holcroft, Lorelle (lorelle.holcroft@bigpond.com) 
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 61
PS 1-28
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study reviews the Gyrocochlea-grade charopid snails of mid-eastern
   Queensland. Gyrocochlea auct., characterised by brown, biconcave shells
   with a diameter of 3-7 mm, has been shown to be polyphyletic (Shea et
   al. 2010). Gyrocochlea s.s. is confirmed as a genus geographically
   restricted to the Border Ranges of south-east Queensland and
   north-eastern New South Wales (Stanisic 1990). This study utilised
   scanning electron microscopy of the shell architecture, qualitative and
   quantitative measurements of conchological features and anatomical
   dissection where suitable specimens were obtainable. Based on shell
   morphology, primarily protoconch sculptural patterns (as defined in
   Holcroft 2018), this study re-assigns three Gyrocochlea-grade species,
   G. chambersae (Stanisic, 2010), G. iuloidea (Forbes, 1851) and G.
   danieli (Stanisic, 2010) to three new genera, Stanisicaropa gen. nov.,
   Whitcochlea gen.nov. and Radiolaropa gen.nov. respectively and diagnoses
   four new genera, Amfractaropa gen.nov., Comularopa gen.nov., Nodularopa
   gen. nov. and Xenoropa gen.nov. Five new species are described:
   Nodularopa samanthae sp. nov., Amfractaropa bretti sp. nov., Comularopa
   georginae sp. nov., Radiolaropa eungella sp. nov., and Xenoropa
   wigtonensis sp. nov.
C1 Holcroft, Lorelle; Griffith Univ, Sch Environm & Sci, Brisbane, Qld,
   Australia, Australia.
EM lorelle.holcroft@bigpond.com
SC Zoology
SN 0079-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell;
   Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Amfractaropa bretti; Comularopa georginae; Nodularopa samanthae;
   Radiolaropa eungella; Xenoropa wigtonensis [Queensland /  / New
   species]. 
   Charopidae; Gyrocochlea [Shell morphology /  / Taxonomic revision]
   [Queensland / Mid east / distribution]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Helicoidea,
   Punctoidea
OR Helix iuloidea - Forbes 1851 (Helicoidea): [Designated type species for
   new genus, Whitcochlea, p. 17]. 
   Amfractaropa (Punctoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Charopidae, Type species
   Amfractaropa bretti, p. 15]. 
   Amfractaropa bretti (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 15]. 
   Charopidae - Hutton 1884 (Punctoidea). 
   Comularopa (Punctoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Charopidae, Type species
   Comularopa georginae, p. 16]. 
   Comularopa georginae (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 16]. 
   Gyrocochlea (Punctoidea).

   genus Whitcochlea, p. 18]. 
   Nodularopa (Punctoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Charopidae, Type species
   Nodularopa samanthae, p. 14]. 
   Nodularopa samanthae (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 14]. 
   Radiolaropa (Punctoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Charopidae, Type species
   Gyrocochlea danieli Stanisic 2010, p. 9]. 
   Radiolaropa danieli - (Stanisic 2010) (Punctoidea): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Gyrocochlea, p. 10]. 
   Radiolaropa eungella (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 10]. 
   Stanisicaropa (Punctoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Charopidae, Type species
   Gyrocochlea chambersae Stanisic 2010, p. 6]. 
   Stanisicaropa chambersae - (Stanisic 2010) (Punctoidea): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Gyrocochlea, p. 6]. 
   Whitcochlea (Punctoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Charopidae, Type species
   Helix iuloidea Forbes 1851, p. 17].

   Transferred from Gyrocochlea, p. 18].

   Xenoropa wigtonensis, p. 19].

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of semi-slug, Fastosarion comerfordae sp.
   nov., from Eungella National Park, mid-eastern Queensland (Gastropoda:
   Eupulmonata: Helicarionidae).
AU Stanisic, John (john.stanisic@qm.qld.gov.au) 
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 61
PS 43-51
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new semi-slug, Fastosarion comerfordae sp. nov., is described from the
   higher elevations of Eungella National Park in mid-eastern Queensland.
   Historically the species has been considered to be conspecific with F.
   superba (Cox, 1871) from Mt Dryander, mid-eastern Queensland.
   Differences in external animal features and penial anatomy are shown to
   separate the new species from F. superba.

TI Three new species of Cladethosoma Chamberlin, 1920 from southeast
   Queensland (Diplopoda: Polydesmida: Paradoxosomatidae).
AU Mesibov, Robert
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 61
PS 53-67
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The eastern Australian millipede genus Cladethosoma Chamberlin, 1920 is
   represented in Queensland by C. monticola sp. nov., C. musgravei sp.
   nov., C. toowoomba sp. nov., and C. uncinatum Jeekel, 1987. The three
   new species all occur in the southeast of the State and are likely to be
   small-range endemics. C. toowoomba sp. nov. was first recorded in 2017
   as a digital image on BowerBird, an Australian citizen science website.

AN ZOOR15509056973
DT Article
TI A revision of Charopidae with a finely cancellate protoconch sculpture
   from mid-eastern Queensland (Eupulmonata: Charopidae).
AU Holcroft, Lorelle (lorelle.holcroft@griffithuni.edu.au) 
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 61
PS 83-107
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study reviews the charopid land snails of mid-eastern Queensland
   possessing finely cancellate sculpture on the protoconch. Microscopic
   features of shell sculpture and qualitative and quantitative
   measurements of conchological features are utilised to delimit species
   due to lack of animal material suitable for DNA analysis. This study
   confirms the generic status of Pereduropa Stanisic, 2010 and lsolderopa
   Stanisic, 2010 and expands the brief descriptions of the species
   previously described in these genera. One new species of Pereduropa, P.
   burwelli sp. nov. and three new species of lsolderopa viz. l. teemburra
   sp. nov., l. diamante sp. nov. and l. whitsunday sp. nov. are described.
   A new genus, Tristanoropa gen. nov, is diagnosed for two new species T.
   hughesae sp. nov. and T conwayensis sp. nov.
C1 Holcroft, Lorelle; Griffith Univ, Australian Rivers Inst, Nathan
   campus,170 Kessels Rd, Nathan, Qld, 4111, Australia, Australia.
EM lorelle.holcroft@griffithuni.edu.au
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0079-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Shell; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Charopidae [Shell morphology / Protoconch scultpture / Taxonomic
   revision] [Queensland / Mid-east / distribution]. 
   Isolderopa diamante; Isolderopa teemburra; Isolderopa whitsunday;
   Pereduropa burwelli; Tristanoropa conwayensis; Tristanoropa hughesae
   [Queensland /  / New species].

OR Charopidae (Punctoidea). 
   Isolderopa diamante (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 98]. 
   Isolderopa teemburra (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 96]. 
   Isolderopa whitsunday (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 97]. 
   Pereduropa burwelli (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 93]. 
   Tristanoropa (Punctoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Charopidae, Type species
   Tristanoropa hughesae, p. 98]. 
   Tristanoropa conwayensis (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 99]. 
   Tristanoropa hughesae (Punctoidea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 99].

PT J
AN ZOOR15509056974
DT Article
TI Trypanorhynch cestodes (Platyhelminthes) parasitic in elasmobranchs and
   crustaceans in Moreton Bay, Queensland.
AU Beveridge, Ian (ibeve@unimelb.edu.au) 
   Schaeffner, Bjoern C.
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 61
PS 109-142
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Examination of 64 elasmobranchs comprising 13 species from Moreton Bay
   yielded 13 identifiable species of cestodes of the order Trypanorhyncha
   Diesling, 1863. Two new species, Dollfusiella armata sp. nov. from
   Maculabatis toshi (Whitley, 1939) and M. cf. astra Last,
   Manjaji-Matsumoto and Pogonoski, 2008, and Dollfusiella pilosa sp. nov.
   from Aetobatus ocellatus (Kuhl, 1823) are described. Prochristianella
   odonoghuei Beveridge, 1990 becomes a junior synonym of Prochristianella
   butlerae Beveridge, 1990 based on identical strobilar and tentacular
   morphologies. Prochristianella omunae Beveridge and Justine, 2010 is
   reported from Australia for the first time, where it was recovered from
   the type host Neotrygon trigonoides (Castelnau, 1873). Additional new
   host records are included as well as extensions of known geographical
   distributions to now include south-eastern Queensland. Metacestodes were
   recovered from the digestive glands of yabbies, Trypaea australis (Dana,
   1852), representing an undescribed species of Dollfusiella. Adults of
   this species were found in the spiral valves of N. trigonoides and Ae.
   ocellatus. Six species of metacestodes of trypanorhynch cestodes were
   recovered from the digestive glands of pistol shrimps, Alpheus spp. (A.
   richardsoni Yaldwyn, 1971 and A. papillosus Banner&Banner, 1982). Of
   these, three were identified as Parachristianella monomegacantha Kruse,
   1959, Prochristianella aciculata Beveridge and Justine, 2010 and
   Zygorhynchus robertsoni Beveridge and Campbell, 1988, the adults of all
   three species being originally reported from batoids. Two undescribed
   species of Dollfusiella and undescribed species of Parachristianella and
   Zygorhynchus were also recovered from alpheid shrimps; definitive hosts
   were identified for each species, but the material available was
   insufficient to allow formal descriptions.
C1 Beveridge, Ian; Univ Melbourne, Fac Vet & Agr Sci, Werribee, Vic, 3030,
   Australia, Australia.
EM ibeve@unimelb.edu.au
RI Schaeffner, Bjoern C./F-9597-2014
OI Schaeffner, Bjoern C./0000-0003-3399-6345
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0079-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean

   robertsoni / New record] [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / ] [ /

   Crustacea; Elasmobranchii [Cestode parasites / Trypanorhyncha / Host

   Moreton Bay / ].

   Queensland / New species from piscean host]. 
   Dollfusiella owensi [Piscean hosts / Hemitrygon fluviorum / New record]
   [ / Maculabatis toshi / ] [ / Maculabatis cf. astra / ] [South Pacific /
   Australia, Queensland, south east / ]. 
   Dollfusiella pilosa [Piscean hosts / Aetobatus ocellatus / New parasite

   piscean host]. 
   Dollfusiella spinulifera [Piscean hosts / Hemitrygon fluviorum / New

   Queensland, Moreton Bay / ]. 
   Glaucostegus typus [Cestode parasites / Parachristianella monomegacantha

   southwelli / ] [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / ] [ / Australia,

   Hemitrygon fluviorum [Cestode parasites / Dollfusiella owensi / New
   record] [ / Dollfusiella spinulifera / ] [ / Prochristianella aciculata
   / ] [ / Zygorhynchus elongatus / ] [South Pacific / Australia,
   Queensland / ] [ / Australia, Queensland, Moreton Bay / ] [ / Australia,
   Queensland, south east / ]. 
   Hispidorhynchus australiensis [Piscean hosts / Aetobatus ocellatus / New
   record] [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland, south east / ]. 
   Kotorella pronosoma [Piscean hosts / Maculabatis toshi / New record]
   [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland, Green Island / ]. 
   Maculabatis cf. astra [Cestode parasites / Dollfusiella armata / New

DT Article
TI Three new species of acotylean polyclads (Platyhelminthes) from
   Queensland, Australia, with the erection of a new genus.
AU Beveridge, Ian (ibeve@unimelb.edu.au) 
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 61
PS 143-153
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Three new acotylean polyclads are described from the littoral zone in
   Queensland. Amyris bulbosa sp. nov. (Notoplanidae Faubel, 1983) is
   distinguished from congeners in possessing a prominent vagina bulbosa.
   Emprosthopharynx heroniensis sp. nov. (Stylochoplanidae Faubel, 1983)
   differs from related species in lacking sub-marginal eyes and tentacles,
   in the anterior position of the cerebral eyes, and possessing few
   ruffles in the pharynx and uterine vesicles. Zygantrella queenslandensis
   gen. nov., sp. nov. is erected as a monotypic genus within the
   Ilyplanidae Faubel, 1983 differing from confamilial genera in lacking a
   prostate but possessing a common gonopore and a penis stylet.
C1 Beveridge, Ian; Univ Melbourne, Fac Vet & Agr Sci, Werribee, Vic, 3030,
   Australia, Australia.
EM ibeve@unimelb.edu.au

   Ocean

   Queensland / New species].

   New associate species] [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / New
   species; crustacean associate]. 
   Paguroidea [Associations / Emprosthopharynx heroniensis
   (Platyhelminthes) / New associate species] [South Pacific / Australia,
   Queensland / New associated platyhelminth species].

DT Article
TI Thirteen new charopid land snails from mid-eastern Queensland
   rainforests (Gastropoda: Eupulmonata: Charopidae).
AU Holcroft, Lorene (lorelle.holcroft@griffithuni.edu.au) 
   Stanisic, John
SO Memoirs of the Queensland Museum
VL 61
PS 155-186
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Thirteen new species of charopid land snail are described from
   mid-eastern Queensland rainforests. These are assigned to four newly
   diagnosed genera: Hirsutaropa sarina gen. et sp. nov., Burwellia
   staceythomsonae gen. et sp. nov., Albiropa mkroscopica gen. et sp. nov.,
   Eungellaropa crediton gen. et sp. nov. and six existing genera:
   Lenwebbia marissae sp.nov., Omphaloropa subvaricosa sp. nov.,
   Amfractaropa southpercyensis sp. nov., Comularopa wendyae sp. nov.,
   Isolderopa gloucester sp. nov., Tristanoropa southmolle sp. nov.,
   Tristanoropa summerae sp. nov., Tristanoropa jaxut sp. nov. and
   Tristanoropa hazelwood sp. nov. An additional six species are recognised
   formally but not formally described due to poor quality material. New
   distribution data is presented for Setomeclea janae Stanisic, 1990,
   Discocharopa aperta (Mollendorff, 1888) and Sinployea intensa lredale,
   1941. The latter two represent new records for mid-eastern Queensland. A
   short discussion on the potential implications of the expanded MEQ
   charopid fauna for east coast biogeography is presented.

DT Article
TI The Early Miocene teleoceratine Prosantorhinus aff. douvillei (Mammalia,
   Perissodactyla, Rhinocerotidae) from Beon 2, Southwestern France.
AU Antoine, Pierre-Olivier (pierre-olivierantoine@umontpellier.fr) 
   Becker, Damien
   Laurent, Yves
   Duranthon, Francis
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 37
IS 2
PS 367-377
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Beon 2 locality, near Montreal-du-Gers in the Garonne Basin, SW France,
   yields a middle Orleanian mammalian assemblage coeval to that of Artenay
   in the Loire Basin (early MN4). Two rhinocerotid species were previously
   mentioned at Beon 2: the small and slender rhinocerotine
   Protaceratherium minutum (Cuvier, 1822) and a large-sized and
   short-limbed teleoceratine provisionally referred to as Diaceratherium
   aurelianense (Nouel, 1866) prior to accurate preparation. The latter
   taxon is documented by a complete skull, isolated teeth, and postcranial
   elements unearthed in 1994-1998, showing the closest morphological
   affinities to Prosantorhinus douvillei (Osborn, 1900) instead, but
   differing from it in several cranio-dental and postcranial aspects
   (e.g., median ridge absent on the occipital condyle, sulcus mylohyoideus
   present on the corpus mandibulae, it with a developed crown, P2
   molariform with a thick protocone and a protoloph joining the ectoloph,
   constricted protocone on M3, p2 with an unconstricted paralophid and a
   lingually open posterior valley, axis-facets transversally concave on
   the atlas, magnum with a long posterior tuberosity, fibula-facet more
   oblique and expansion of the Cc1 facet wide and low on the astragalus).
   The concerned remains are described and illustrated for the first time
   here, allowing for a new taxonomic assignment for this teleoceratine
   (Prosantorhinus aff. douvillei). A calcaneus from Beon 2 is further
   assigned to an unidentified representative of Plesiaceratherium. The
   revised Beon 2 rhinocerotid assemblage consists of three species:
   Prosantorhinus aff. douvillei (dominant), Protaceratherium minutum, and
   Plesiaceratherium sp. (large-sized).
C1 Antoine, Pierre-Olivier; Univ Montpellier, CNRS, Pl Eugene Bataillon,
   Montpellier, F-34095, France, France.
EM pierre-olivierantoine@umontpellier.fr
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0253-6730
BD Systematics; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Plesiaceratherium; Prosantorhinus aff. douvillei; Protaceratherium
   minutum [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [France / Gers,
   Montreal-du-Gers, Beon / ] [Miocene / Middle Orleanian / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Perissodactyla, Rhinocerotidae
OR Plesiaceratherium (Rhinocerotidae): [Fossil]. 
   Prosantorhinus aff. douvillei (Rhinocerotidae): [Fossil]. 
   Protaceratherium minutum - (Cuvier 1822) (Rhinocerotidae): [Fossil].

DT Article
TI Origin and hidden diversity within the poorly known Galapagos snake
   radiation (Serpentes: Dipsadidae).
AU Zaher, Hussam (hussam.zaher@gmail.com) 
   Yanez-Munoz, Mario H.
   Rodrigues, Miguel T.
   Graboski, Roberta
   Machado, Fabio A.
   Altamirano-Benavides, Marco
   Bonatto, Sandro L.
   Grazziotin, Felipe G.
SO Systematics and Biodiversity
VL 16
IS 7
PS 614-642
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 3
U2 6
AB Galapagos snakes are among the least studied terrestrial vertebrates of
   the Archipelago. Here, we provide a phylogenetic analysis and a time
   calibrated tree for the group, based on a sampling of the major
   populations known to occur in the Archipelago. Our study revealed the
   presence of two previously unknown species from Santiago and Rabida
   Islands, and one from Tortuga, Isabela, and Fernandina. We also
   recognize six additional species of Pseudalsophis in the Galapagos
   Archipelago (Pseudalsophis biserialis from San Cristobal, Floreana and
   adjacent islets; Pseudalsophis hoodensis from Espanola and adjacent
   islets; Pseudalsophis dorsalis from Santa Cruz, Baltra, Santa Fe, and
   adjacent islets; Pseudalsophis occidentalis from Fernandina, Isabela,
   and Tortuga; Pseudalsophis slevini from Pinzon, and Pseudalsophis
   steindachneri from Baltra, Santa Cruz and adjacent islets). Our time
   calibrated tree suggests that the genus Pseudalsophis colonized the
   Galapagos Archipelago through a single event of oceanic dispersion from
   the coast of South America that occurred at approximately between 6.9Ma
   and 4.4Ma, near the Miocene/Pliocene boundary.www.zoobank.org/urn: lsid:
   zoobank.org: pub:2679FD19-01E5-48FE-A0DA-A88FF145DE56

   SP, BR-04263000 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM hussam.zaher@gmail.com

DT Article
TI Molecular phylogeny and systematics of Acrotoma (Gastropoda:
   Clausiliidae) from the Caucasus.
AU Hausdorf, Bernhard (hausdorf@zoologie.uni-hamburg.de) 
   Walther, Frank
   Neiber, Marco T.
SO Systematics and Biodiversity
VL 16
IS 7
PS 692-713
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The land snail genus Acrotoma (Clausiliidae) from the western Greater
   Caucasus is revised and a molecular phylogenetic analysis of the genus
   is presented. Shells and, as far as known, genitalia of 13 species are
   described and figured. Two species are described as new to science,
   i.e., A. vespa sp. nov. and A. enguriensis sp. nov. The diagnostic
   characteristics are summarized in a table. All locality records are
   listed and shown in distribution maps. Based on Bayesian, Maximum
   likelihood and Maximum parsimony analyses of mitochondrial and nuclear
   DNA sequences we revise the classification of the genus and suggest a
   division into three subgenera, Iliamneme, Acrotomina and Acrotoma s.
   str. The radiation of the Acrotoma species in the Pliocene and
   Quaternary might have been triggered by the orogenesis of the Greater
   Caucasus, which created habitats, such as canyons and alpine
   environments, to which the Acrotoma species adapted.www.zoobank.org/urn:
   lsid: zoobank.org: pub:6B14BE68-0E07-42EF-B08D-A75B2138B72

   Hamburg, D-20146, Germany, Germany.

PT J
AN ZOOR15509055694
DT Article
TI Molecules and morphology reveal a new aberrant harvestman genus of
   Ortholasmatinae (Opiliones, Dypsnoi, Nemastomatidae) from Mexico.
AU Cruz-Lopez, Jesus A. (thelyphonidito@gmail.com) 
   Cruz-Bonilla, Akeri
   Francke, Oscar F.
SO Systematics and Biodiversity
VL 16
IS 7
PS 714-729
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Ortholasmatinae is one of the most striking groups of Opiliones, because
   its members exhibit a peculiar dorsal ornamentation pattern of cells,
   formed by fusion of anvil-shaped tubercles. During the systematic
   revision of several specimens of ortholasmatines, we found specimens
   with shared morphological characters with two genera Trilasma
   Goodnight&Goodnight, 1942 and Dendrolasma Banks, 1894. In order to
   investigate their phylogenetic relationships, we performed model-based
   phylogenetic analyses using the mitochondrial protein-encoding
   cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (CO1) and the complete nuclear ribosomal
   small subunit 18S, including members of the five genera of this
   subfamily. The results support the creation of Cryptolasma Cruz-Lopez,
   Cruz-Bonilla&Francke, gen. nov., and two new species: Cryptolasma
   aberrante Cruz-Lopez, Cruz-Bonilla&Francke, sp. nov. (type species) and
   Cryptolasma citlaltepetl Cruz-Lopez, Cruz-Bonilla&Francke, sp. nov.,
   which are from Xalapa and Orizaba Volcano, Veracruz, respectively.
   Additionally, our results suggest Ruaxphilos petrukenvitchou
   Goodnight&Goodnight, 1945 is a nomina dubia. This study represents the
   first molecular hypothesis of Ortholasmatinae relationships, with
   Cryptolasma as the sister of the remaining
   ortholasmatine.www.zoobank.org/urn: lsid: zoobank.org:
   pub:3730EE48-9802-4B06-9DDF-EC1AFE9A3B61

DT Article
TI NEW GENUS AND NEW SPECIES OF THE FAMILY ISSIDAE (HEMIPTERA:
   AUCHENORRHYNCHA: FULGOROIDEA) FROM SOUTHERN SPAIN.
AU Gnezdilov, V.M. (vgnezdilov@zin.ru) 
   den Bieman, C.F.M.
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 322
IS 4
PS 389-397
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Granadus albirhombus gen. et sp. nov. is described from the Granada
   Province in Spain. This new genus and new species is characterized by a
   complex of features distinguishing it from other genera of the subtribe
   Issina: metope with only median carina; coryphe twice as wide as long
   medially; fore wings with wide hypocostal plate; forewing veins sequence
   - R 2 M 3 CuA 1; hind wings rudimentary; hind tibia with 2 lateral
   spines in its distal half; first metatarsomere with 2 latero-apical
   spines and 9 intermediate spines in continuous row; phallobase slightly
   curved (in lateral view), narrow, dorso-lateral lobes fused dorsally;
   each dorso-lateral lobe of the phallobase with semicircular subapical
   process; ventral phallobase lobe long and wide, almost as long as
   dorso-lateral lobes, with 2 longitudinal lobes basally covering aedeagal
   hooks; aedeagus with pair of short ventral hooks arising in its basal
   third and directed to its base; hind margin of female sternite VII with
   large rectangular median process; gonoplacs rounded; lateral fields of
   posterior connective laminae of gonapophyses IX lobe-shaped; median
   field of the laminae in shape of large single lobe; anterior connective
   lamina of gonapophyse VIII with 3 rounded teeth in apical group and 2
   teeth and 3 combs in lateral group.

   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI SYSTEMATICS OF THE AMERICAN KATYDIDS (ORTHOPTERA: TETTIGONIIDAE).
   COMMUNICATION 8.
AU Gorochov, A., V (orthopt@zin.ru) 
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 322
IS 4
PS 398-456
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genera Rhammatopoda Redtenbacher, 1892 (Mecopodinae), Gnathoclita
   Hagenbach, 1841 (Pleminiinae), Theia Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1891, Viadana
   Walker, 1869, Tomeophera Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1878, Abrodiaeta
   Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1878, Aganacris Walker, 1871, Theudoria Stab 1874,
   Ligocatinus Rehn, 1901, gen. resurr. (it is restored from synonym to
   Homotoicha Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1891), Ceraiaella Hebard, 1933,
   Enthephippion Bruner, 1915, Parableta Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1878,
   Chloroscirtus Saussure et Pictet, 1897 and Euthyrrachis
   Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1878 (Phaneropterinae), as well as Phlugiola Karny,
   1907 (Meconematinae) are considered. The following new taxa are
   described from Peru, Ecuador, Brazil, Bolivia, Surinam, Paraguay and
   Colombia: Rhammatopoda calabaza sp. nov. from Peru; Rh. oxapampa sp.
   nov. from Peru; Gnathoclita (Gnathoclita) izerskyi sp. nov. from Peru;
   Theia (Oxyprorella) hetairomima sp. nov. from Peru; Viadana
   (Paraviadana) ashaninka sp. nov. from Peru; V. (Viadana) rostrata sp.
   nov. from Peru; V. (V.) parobliqua sp. nov. from Ecuador; Tomeophera
   cellulata sp. nov. from Peru; T. parallela sp. nov. from Peru;
   Abrodiaeta (Abrodiaeta) macricula sp. nov. from Peru; A. (Sclerodiaeta)
   propinqua subgen. et sp. nov. from Brazil; A. (S.) fruhstorferi sp. nov.
   from Brazil; A. (Barodiaeta) minasgerais subgen. et sp. nov. from
   Brazil; Rostellula minutissima gen. et sp. nov. from Peru; R. santacruzi
   sp. nov. from Bolivia; Separatula adunca gen. et sp. nov. from Peru and
   Ecuador; Theudoria (Ctenophorema stat. nov) pyrrhopterus surinam subsp.
   nov. from Surinam; Ligocatinus paraguay sp. nov. from Paraguay;
   Ceraiaella zebrina pudica subsp. nov. from Peru; Stylibleta subgen. nov.
   and Oscarbleta subgen. nov. in Parableta s.l.; P. (Parableta) cercata
   sp. nov. from Ecuador; P. (P.) niko - laii sp. nov. from Peru; P. (?P.)
   denticulata sp. nov. from Bolivia; Chloroscirtus columbianus sp. nov.
   from Colombia; Euthyrrhachis consobrina elsol subsp. nov. from Bolivia;
   Phlugiola paratushali sp. nov. from Peru. One former genus is reduced to
   the subgenus Homotoicha Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1891, stat. nov. of the genus
   Theudoria. Amaura olivacea Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1891, A. borelli
   Giglio-Tos, 1897, Ligocatinus sordidus Rehn, 1921, L. minutus Rehn, 1921
   and Phaneroptera quadrivittata Piza, 1967, considered previously as
   belonging to three species of Homotoicha, as well as Phaneropterella
   infumata Piza, 1977 are transferred to the genus Enthephippion with
   establishing the following synonymy: Phaneropterella Piza, 1977, syn.
   nov. = Enthephippion; E. olivaceum comb. nov. = Ph. quadrivittata; E.
   borelli sp. resurr. et comb. nov. (it is restored from synonymy to E.
   olivaceum) = L. sordidus syn. nov.; E. minutum comb. nov. and E.
   infumatum comb. nov. are possible synonyms of each other. Homotoicha
   amazoniensis Cadena-Castaneda, 2015 is here included in the genus
   Euthyrrhachis (as E. amazoniensis comb. nov.). Some other new data on
   the above-mentioned genera are also given. One former genus is reduced
   to the subgenus Homotoicha Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1891, stat. nov. of the
   genus Theudoria. Amaura olivacea Brunner-Wattenwyl, 1891, A. borelli
   Giglio-Tos, 1897, Ligocatinus sordidus Rehn, 1921, L. minutus Rehn, 1921
   and Phaneroptera quadrivittata Piza, 1967, considered previously as
   belonging to three species of Homotoicha, as well as Phaneropterella
   infumata Piza, 1977 are transferred to the genus Enthephippion with
   establishing the following synonymy: Phaneropterella Piza, 1977, syn.
   nov. = Enthephippion; E. olivaceum comb. nov. = Ph. quadrivittata; E.
   borelli sp. resurr. et comb. nov. (it is restored from synonymy to E.
   olivaceum) = L. sordidus syn. nov.; E. minutum comb. nov. and E.
   infumatum comb. nov. are possible synonyms of each other. Homotoicha
   amazoniensis Cadena-Castarieda, 2015 is here included in the genus
   Euthyrrhachis (as E. amazoniensis comb. nov.). Some other new data on
   the above-mentioned genera are also given.

DT Article
TI NEW GENUS FOR THIONIA GIBBICOLLIS DOZIER, 1931 (HEMIPTERA:
   AUCHENORRHYNCHA: FULGOROIDEA: NOGODINIDAE) FROM HAITI.
AU Gnezdilov, V.M. (vgnezdilov@zin.ru) 
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 322
IS 4
PS 457-462
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus, Dozierana gen. nov., is erected for Thionia gibbicollis
   Dozier, 1931 which is transferred from the family Issidae Spinola, 1839
   to the family Nogodinidae Melichar 1898, subfamily Colpopterinae
   Gnezdilov, 2003. This new combination increases the fauna of
   Colpopterinae of Haiti Island up to 3 genera with 5 species.
   Accordingly, the family Issidae is no longer formally known from the
   island. Dozierana gen. nov. is characterized by wide metope, with
   distinct median carina running through postclypeus and very weak
   sublateral carinae, upper margin of metope concave; coryphe 3 times as
   wide as long medially; large ocelli present; pronotum short, with 4
   lateral carinae, its anterior margin strongly convex and posterior
   margin strongly concave; mesonotum 7 times as long as pronotum along
   midline, greatly elevated (hump-shaped) along median carina, with two
   lateral carinae joined with median one in shape of inverted "V"; fore
   wings wide, with wide hypocostal plate and rich cross-venation through
   whole wing, except subcostal area; basal cell large oblong-oval; costal
   vein with distinct upper keel appearing as a separate vein; clavus as
   long as whole wing, open; hind tibiae with single lateral spine
   subapically.
C1 Gnezdilov, V.M.; Russian Acad Sci, Zool Inst, 1 Univ Skaya Emb, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM vgnezdilov@zin.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0206-0477
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Issidae, Nogodinidae
OR Thionia gibbicollis - Dozier 1931 (Issidae): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Dozierana, p. 458]. 
   Dozierana (Nogodinidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Colpopterini, Type species
   Thionia gibbicollis Dozier 1931, p. 458]. 
   Dozierana gibbicollis - (Dozier 1931) (Nogodinidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Thionia, p. 460].
