PT J
AN ZOOR15507041670
DT Article
TI TWO NEW MACRAUCHENIIDS (MAMMALIA: LITOPTERNA) FROM THE LATE MIDDLE
   MIOCENE (LAVENTAN SOUTH AMERICAN LAND MAMMAL AGE) OF QUEBRADA HONDA,
   BOLIVIA.
AU McGrath, Andrew J. (amcgrath@umail.ucsb.edu) 
   Anaya, Federico
   Croft, Darin A.
SO Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology
VL 38
IS 3
PS e1461632
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe two new macraucheniid litopterns from the late middle
   Miocene (ca. 13 Ma) Quebrada Honda Fauna of southern Bolivia. The
   holotype of 'Theosodon' arozquetai, sp. nov., is a partial cranium
   preserving RI2-M3 and LP1-M3, elements of the hind limb, and two
   metapodials. An upper cheek tooth series is also referred to this
   species. The holotype of Llullataruca shockeyi, gen. et sp. nov., is a
   mandible preserving nearly the entire lower dentition. A dentary,
   several upper teeth, and a variety of postcranial elements are also
   referred to this species. Two specimens from the slightly older locality
   of Cerdas, Bolivia, are assigned to L. cf. shockeyi. A phylogenetic
   analysis recovers 'T' arozquetai as sister to Theosodon spp., and we
   provisionally refer it to that genus pending its revision. Llullataruca
   shockeyi forms a polytomy with three late Oligocene-early Miocene
   'cramaucheniines' and the later-diverging macraucheniids. The body mass
   of 'T' arozquetai is estimated at 80.8-116.2 kg, slightly smaller than
   early Miocene T garretorum. Llullataruca shockeyi is among the smallest
   known macraucheniids based on dental dimensions and is estimated at
   35.3-54.6 kg. Theosodon' arozquetai and L. shockeyi are the first
   well-characterized macraucheniids from the middle Miocene, and the
   latter species demonstrates that relatively early-diverging lineages
   persisted at least 7 million years longer in tropical latitudes than
   they did in Patagonia.
C1 McGrath, Andrew J.; Univ Calif Santa Barbara, Dept Earth Sci, Santa
   Barbara, CA, 93106, USA, USA.
EM amcgrath@umail.ucsb.edu
OI Croft, Darin/0000-0002-6514-2187; McGrath, Andrew/0000-0003-0977-569X
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0272-4634
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Llullataruca [Miocene /  / New genus]. 
   Llullataruca shockeyi; Theosodon arozquetai [Bolivia /  / new species]
   [Miocene /  / ]. 
   Macraucheniidae [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Bolivia / Quebrada Honda /
   ] [Miocene / Middle Miocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Litopterna
OR Llullataruca (Litopterna): [Gen nov, Of family Macraucheniidae, Type
   species Llullataruca shockeyi, p. 8, Miocene; Fossil]. 
   Llullataruca shockeyi (Litopterna): [Sp nov, Bolivia, Miocene, P. 8;
   Fossil]. 
   Macraucheniidae - Gervais 1855 (Litopterna): [Fossil]. 
   Theosodon arozquetai (Litopterna): [Sp nov, Bolivia, Miocene, P. 4;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15507041674
DT Article
TI SYSTEMATIC AND MORPHOGEOMETRIC ANALYSES OF PACHYRUKHINAE (MAMMALIA,
   HEGETOTHERIIDAE) FROM THE HUAYQUERIAS, MENDOZA (ARGENTINA):
   BIOSTRATIGRAPHIC AND EVOLUTIONARY IMPLICATIONS.
AU Vera, Barbara (barbara.vera@comahue-conicet.gob.ar) 
   Ercoli, Marcos D.
SO Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology
VL 38
IS 3
PS e1473410
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We present new remains of Pachyrukhinae (Hegetotheriidae) from the
   Huayquerias del Este (Mendoza, Argentina). We identify Tremacyllus
   impressus, proposing T. subdiminutus as a synonym and providing new data
   on postcranial bones for this taxon. Tremacyllus specimens from Mendoza
   reveal a wide and continuous morphological variation that encompasses
   the morphological differences of species previously considered valid,
   emphasizing the need for a systematic study focused on all
   representatives of the genus. We also recognize Paedotherium typicum,
   which shows a combination of features differing from other species of
   the genus. The large sample allows us to improve the diagnosis for both
   the genus Tremacyllus and the species T. impressus and P. typicum. Both
   species coexist in the Huayquerias Formation; T. impressus is also
   present in the Tunuyan Formation, whereas the specimens recognized as
   Paedotherium in this unit were not identifiable at species level.
   Applying geometric morphometric methods on the dentition, we partially
   support the taxonomic decisions. We present the first phylogenetic
   analysis including all the species of Tremacyllus and Paedotherium,
   using morphological characters of skull and postcranium. According to
   our results, Tremacyllus is a monophyletic group supported by two
   synapomorphies, whereas Paedotherium is paraphyletic, in agreement with
   the prior hypothesis. The record of Paedotherium typicum presented here
   extends the biochron of this taxon into the late Miocene, which is
   relevant for establishing biostratigraphic and paleobiogeographic
   affinities with other Miocene localities.
C1 Vera, Barbara; CONICET, CIEMEP, Roca 780, Esquel, Chubut, RA-9200,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM barbara.vera@comahue-conicet.gob.ar
OI Ercoli, Marcos/0000-0003-2695-2723
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 0272-4634
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy; Biometrics;
   Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Paedotherium; Tremacyllus [Biometrics / Morphogeometrics / systematic
   revision] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Morphological variation /  / ] [Argentina /
   Mendoza, Huayqueias del Este / stratigraphical distribution] [Pliocene /
    / ] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates

PT J
AN ZOOR15507039691
DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Pugillaria Iredale, 1924 (Mollusca: Panpulmonata:
   Siphonariidae).
AU Jenkins, Bruce W. (bruce.jenkins@austmus.gov.au) 
SO Molluscan Research
VL 38
IS 4
PS 274-286
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The species of Pugillaria Iredale, 1924 are revised and redescribed.
   Having not been described adequately, the type species Siphonaria stowae
   Verco, 1906 of the genus Pugillaria has remained confused and hence the
   status and validity of the genus uncertain. Previous assessments of S.
   stowae were based solely on the interpretation of shell and radula
   characteristics. Three species of Pugillaria are described, two are new
   and all are endemic to Australia. Pugillaria species are amongst the
   smallest known members of the Siphonariidae. They are very uncommon and
   have probably been overlooked as juveniles of larger co-existing
   siphonariid or patelliform species in collections. They have a
   distinctive shell morphology, reproductive system and radula. The genus
   is differentiated from other siphonariid genera (Siphonaria Sowerby,
   1823, Benhamina Finlay, 1927 and Williamia Monterosato, 1884) as well as
   the coexisting Trimusculus Schmidt, 1818 (Ellobiidae).
C1 Jenkins, Bruce W.; Australian Museum, Res Inst, 1 William St, Sydney,
   NSW, Australia, Australia.
EM bruce.jenkins@austmus.gov.au
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology
SN 1323-5818
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Shell; Digestive system; Buccal region;
   Reproduction; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Pugillaria [Shell morphology /  / taxonomic revision] [Radula /  / ]
   [Reproductive system /  / ] [South Indian Ocean / Australia /
   distribution] [South Pacific /  / ]. 
   Pugillaria emergens [South Pacific / Australia, New South Wales / New
   species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Basommatophora,
   Siphonarioidea

   Pugillaria emergens (Siphonarioidea): [Sp nov, Australia, New South
   Wales (marine), P. 279]. 
   Siphonaria stowae - Verco 1906 (Siphonarioidea): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 276].

DT Article
TI Revisionary notes on Siniconops Chen, 1939 (Diptera: Conopidae),
   together with a key to known species.
AU Stuke, Jens-Hermann
SO Oriental Insects
VL 52
IS 4
PS 342-368
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A key to the 11 valid species of Siniconops Chen, 1939 is presented.
   Physocephala celebensis de Meijere, 1910 is transferred into Siniconops
   (comb. nov.) and interpreted as a senior synonym of Siniconops
   microvalvus (Krober, 1910) (syn. nov.). Two additional synonyms are
   introduced: Siniconops cheni Qiao & Chao, 1998=Siniconops grandens
   Camras, 1960 (syn. nov.) and Siniconops curtirostris (Krober, 1916) =
   Siniconops sepulchralis (Brunetti, 1912) (syn. nov.). Siniconops
   pilosusspec. nov. (India) and Siniconops kroeberispec. nov. (Malaysia)
   are newly described. New distribution data are listed for an additional
   six species from China, Indonesia, the Philippines, Russia, South Korea,
   Taiwan and Vietnam.
SC Zoology
SN 0030-5316
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; India
DE Siniconops [Oriental region /  / Distribution; taxonomic revision]. 
   Siniconops fuscatus [Vietnam /  / New record]. 
   Siniconops granden [China /  / New record] [South Korea /  / ]. 
   Siniconops kroeberi [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Siniconops pilosus [Fujian /  / New species] [Himachal Pradesh /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Conopidae
OR Physocephala celebensis - de Meijere 1910 (Conopidae): [Referred to,
   Siniconops, p. 353]. 
   Siniconops - Chen 1939 (Conopidae): [Key to species, P. 345]. 
   Siniconops celebensis - (de Meijere 1910) (Conopidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Physocephala, p. 353; Syn nov, Siniconops microvalvus
   (Kroeber 1930), p. 353]. 
   Siniconops fuscatus (Conopidae): [New record]. 
   Siniconops granden - Camras 1960 (Conopidae): [Syn nov, Siniconops cheni
   Qiao & Chao 1998, p. 358; New record]. 
   Siniconops kroeberi (Conopidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 359]. 
   Siniconops pilosus (Conopidae): [Sp nov, Fujian, P. 363]. 
   Siniconops sepulchralis - (Brunetti 1912) (Conopidae): [Syn nov,
   Siniconops curtirostris (Kroeber 1916), p. 367].

PT J
AN ZOOR15507040736
DT Article
TI New Early Paleocene (Danian) dinoflagellate cyst species from the Ormen
   Lange Field, MOre Basin, Norwegian Continental Shelf.
AU Vieira, Manuel (Manuel.Vieira@Shell.com) 
   Mahdi, Salih
   Osterloff, Peter
SO Palynology
VL 42
IS 2
PS 180-198
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB A high-resolution palynological study of a recently acquired core from
   the southern part of the Ormen Lange field (Norway) over the Danian-aged
   reservoir interval revealed rich, diverse and well-preserved palynomorph
   assemblages. Review of these assemblages has allowed the opportunity to
   formally describe some dinoflagellate cysts previously left in open
   nomenclature and others recognised for the first time in this well. We
   propose in this paper the formal description of 10 new species:
   Achomosphaera eggadania sp. nov., Achomosphaera progranulata sp. nov.,
   Areoligera constricta sp. nov., Areoligera pauciornata sp. nov.,
   Deflandrea variabilis sp. nov., Eurydinium ovatum sp. nov.,
   Glaphyrocysta pseudoreticulata sp. nov., Hystrichosphaeridium
   pachydermum sp. nov., Operculodinium runtata sp. nov. and
   Phthanoperidinium ormenlangei sp. nov. All the key diagnostic and
   morphological features of each species are discussed and compared with
   those of other forms outside and within the same genera. The new species
   presented all range throughout the Danian (Early Paleocene) and can be
   used in conjunction with other previously published markers to support
   and enhance the stratigraphic breakdown and subdivision of the reservoir
   interval across the Ormen Lange field, and potentially other areas in
   the North Sea basin.
C1 Vieira, Manuel; Shell UK Ltd, 1 Altens Farm Rd, Aberdeen, AB12 3FY,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM Manuel.Vieira@Shell.com
RI Vieira, Manuel/AAY-4474-2020
OI Vieira, Manuel/0000-0002-2389-4583

PT J
AN ZOOR15507040738
DT Article
TI Tonian (Neoproterozoic) eukaryotic and prokaryotic organic-walled
   microfossils from the upper Visingso Group, Sweden.
AU Loron, Corentin
   Moczydlowska, Malgorzata (malgo.vidal@pal.uu.se) 
SO Palynology
VL 42
IS 2
PS 220-254
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 1
U2 13
AB The diversification of protists and multicellular microorganisms is
   recorded in numerous worldwide Tonian age successions, including the
   Visingso Group in Sweden. The Visingso Group contains a taxonomically
   rich assemblage of cyanobacteria, stromatolites, algal phytoplankton and
   vase-shaped microfossils. A new record of organic-walled microfossils
   from the Visingso 1 drillcore reveals the high taxonomic diversity.
   Several species are reported for the first time from the Visingso Group,
   and one new species Leiosphaeridia gorda n. sp. is described. They are
   in gross phycoma-like cysts of the prasinophycean algae
   Pterospermopsimorpha, Pterospermella, Simia, Macroptycha and
   Dictyotidium. Morphologically similar to zygotic cysts of chlorophycean
   algae are Leiosphaeridia gorda n. sp., Cerebrosphaera, Culcitulisphaera
   and Lanulatisphaera. Schizofusa may represent the earliest yellow-green
   algae of the Eustigmatiphyte among Stramenopiles. The recorded
   biodiversity documents the global trend in the evolution of eukaryotic
   protists during the Tonian Period and the increased radiation of
   numerous, presumably photoautotrophic biotas, representing various algal
   lineages.
C1 Moczydlowska, Malgorzata; Uppsala Univ, Dept Earth Sci, Villavagen 16,
   Uppsala, SE-75236, Sweden, Sweden.
EM malgo.vidal@pal.uu.se
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0191-6122

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Precambrian
DE Animalia; Protozoa [Fossil assemblages /  / New record; systematics;
   organic-walled microfossils] [Sweden / Visingso Island / ] [Proterozoic
   / Neoproterozoic / ]. 
   Leiosphaeridia gorda [Sweden /  / new species] [Proterozoic /  / ].

   [Comb nov, Transferred from Kaibabia, p. 231].

   nov, Pterospermopsimorpha binata Timofeev 1966, p. 239]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15507040738
DA 2020-09-17
ER

EF
